group_siblings.title: Forum of protest

results.title: Forum of protest
results.creator_credit: Gary Cunningham, Richard Linning and HSV7 Melbourne
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Week”.
Prompted by the statement by the then Victorian Premier, Sir Henry Bolte, to the effect that there would be no State Parliamentary House of Review within a generation, this television current affairs report dedicates itself to the history and protocol of the Victorian Legislative Council as well as the architectural features of its chambers. A fairly dry “talking heads” program.

results.title: Shadow of the Ruhr
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
For fifty years the Ruhr Valley has been the key to Germany’s economy in war and peace; but because it is essentially a heavy-industry area, the Ruhr is also the arsenal and aggressive potential of Germany. At the end of World War 2, the Ruhr Valley was in ruins - factories, foundries, mines, warehouses, and homes reduced to rubble and ashes, the people short of food, without shelter, and with little prospect of employment. The policy of the Allies immediately after WW2 was to prevent the Ruhr from ever producing arms again; but as friction between the great nations has increased in the post-war world, the western powers have once again begun to develop the Ruhr’s armaments industries.

results.title: Coal crisis
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
Part of a series of films on the importance of coal in the national economy of Great Britain, examining the problems facing the National Coal Board in 1947. This film makes an urgent plea for recognition of the coal industry to Britain and the steps that must be takn to stabilise the industry and increase its output.

results.title: The Future of one million Africans
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
A study of conditions in Bechuanaland, Basutoland, and Swaziland, the British protectorates on the borders of South Africa. The resources and products of each territory are looked at in turn. The contrast between modern ways of living and the old tribal traditions. How the problem of drought, with consequent soil erosion and deterioration is being tackled everywhere by engineering, agricultural and pastoral development. Improvements in medicine and education. How many of the natives leave the protectorates for short period to earn money in South African mines. Explains and discusses the political setup; how the High Commissioner worked with the help of Residential Commissioners and native Advisory Councils. Brief history of South African relations with the protectorates.

results.title: Lancashire's time for adventure
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
For more than 200 years cotton, grown on the other side of the world, has been coming to Britain to be spun and woven. A moist climate, money for the development of mills, and inventors whose machines taught mass-production to the world - Lancashire had all these. But today one-third of Lancashire’s spindles and looms are idle. The memory of past booms and slumps has resulted in a grave shortage of operators. Schemes to improve working conditions and wages have been put into operation.

results.title: Struggle for oil
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”
Discusses the importance of oil in the world of today. Traces the growth of the oil industry from the beginning of the century, during the first and second world wars and in the post-war era. The Middle East as a source of oil is considered and the need for political stability in these areas emphasised. This stability can only be guaranteed if the rulers of these countries use profits from oil to improve the conditions of the people.

results.title: Fight for a fuller life
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
A survey of the educational facilities available to the British citizen. The examination begins with the Universities: increased attendance, coupled with a shortage of accommodation, has created a situation in which professors and tutors have less time for research and personal tuition so vital to university life. The film also discusses the technical training colleges and the facilities provided by the local authorities for vocational training. The last secion deals with adult education and the organisations that are responsible for the provision of expert tuition in a wide variety of subjects.

results.title: Ceylon: the new dominion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
A survey of the history and position (as at 1948) of Ceylon (Sri Lanka), the newest Dominion of the British Commonwealth. Shows the civilization of the Lion People who invaded Ceylon from Northern India; the influence of Portugese and Dutch colonization which preceded British rule. The achievements of a 150 years of British rule are evaluated. The practical results of British government in terms of increased production of tea, rubber and coconuts are illustrated. Shows the modern educational system; defeat of malaria; extension of irrigation and recolonization of the north; difficulties facing the new Dominion. The population of six and a half million people is made up of five races with four religions and three languages. Poverty, lack of finance, high cost of imported food are barriers to progress, but progressive social schemes have been started.
